questions.question_text:
An administrator is creating a new user account and wants to grant access to only the resources required to perform the user's assigned job duties.
Which of the following will the administrator MOST likely use?

discussion.content: principle of least privilege   Accounts should have permission to access only the resources they need and no more.
ACL is something used by the firewall that restricts what traffic that can go in/out of the network. So, A must be ruled out.

Google said "The principle of least privilege (POLP) is a concept in computer security that limits users' access rights to only what are strictly required to do their jobs. Users are granted permission to read, write or execute only the files or resources necessary to do their jobs".

comments.content: The fact that the question asks for MOST likely makes me feel that A is correct.
it doesn't say tool. Least Privilege is the best answer because it would explain why someone would do the other answers that seem correct

discussion.content:
Well this question, as it is written, is a massive problem. Both A and C could be correct as they are the tools the admin will use to restrict access, depending on the system. Of the two, A is more likely as a filesystem ACL can be set at domain level (therefore across OS and work stations) whereas Directory Permissions is for Linux and used more for local machines/accounts (also unlikely that the user will be on Linux).
Technically the admin is using the PRINCIPLE of Least Privelage however this is just a concept, not a tool used when creating an account. 
So there are 3 viable answers, 2 that can be considered correct at the same time. The question does not state if it is asking about the tool or concept...

questions.question_text:
Many of the files in a user's network folder have a new file extension and are inaccessible. After some troubleshooting, a technician discovers a text document that states the files were intentionally encrypted, and a large sum of money is required to decrypt them.
Which of the following should the technician do to recover the files?

discussion.content: Seems to me the question asks very specifically about restoring the files, not the malware process, not the next step in the process but how would one get back files that are encrypted due to ransomware. The answer to that is that you have to restore from a last known good back up. If it asked about how to deal with the malware that may have resulted in the ransomware or what is the first thing to do, then the other answers make sense.
the question should ask what the technician should do "First" to recover the files. but it only asks what to do recover files only which should be restore files....

Selected Answer: D
It looks like it doesn't make sense, but have to really pay attention to the details.

Everybody I thinking is a ransomware and I think is right.

Now... we are talking about folders on the network that ate claimed as locked. 
A ransomware really unlikely is in the server, but is probably in the device. If you try to access from a clean computer, probably the folders will still be accessible.

So the problem is not the network, but the device.

The solution is to disconnect the device and sort it. Once reconnected to the network the folders will be available again

Selected Answer: A
The question is very specific by asking what to do to "recover the files" so the answer should be A. It's not asking what to do First or Next...
It's CompTIA people...the answer is D.

comments.content: Makes sense for this question too because restoring the backup does not remove the threat therefore it could simply encrypt the files again after restoration.

discussion.content: CompTIA logic, always quarantine threats before taking other action.

comments.content: Go study how network folders work some more, particularly Folder Redirection. Software installed on a PC can definitely modify server-based user files.
C is the most suitable answer as the question stated "...to recover the files..."

discussion.content: Its a network folder, those are usually on a server and accessed via user profile. Doing anything to the computer most likely wouldn't resolve the issue. Its either A or C

choices.B: Perform a System Restore on the computer.
choices.D: Disconnect the computer from the network.
choices.A: Restore the network folder from a backup.
choices.C: Update the malware scanner and run a full scan.

questions.question_text:
A business unit wants to upgrade the current version of its loan processing software. A manager is putting together a change management request and gathering information on the software.
Which of the following would be MOST important during this phase of the request process?

discussion.content: This question needs to be more specific. all of the process in the change management is important..... another poorly written question to catch you out even though you know the full process.

comments.content: Risk Analysis is also my best guess. He is still on Step 1 Request for Change and Risk Analysis is part of the documentation for that RFC (according to ITIL).
I would stand for risk analysis, how would you put a proposal to client without the risk acknowledgment?

His manager is still in the process of gathering information so according to the change management steps, he's still in the first two steps. Answer in this case would most likely be Risk Analysis since he hasn't identified if the change is low risk or high risk.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Before the change = Document the change, Purpose of chnage, Scope of change, Risk analysis

During and after the change= Implement Plan A( Plan B in case plan A fails), Rollout/Backup plan if both fails, User Acceptance Testing, Board Review & Approval

comments.content:
The question pretty clearly states that they have not yet implemented the change. 

Moving forward with that information your own breakdown of the steps disqualifies B. C, Risk Analysis is the correct answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
1. Purpose
2. Scope 
3. Risk Analysis 
4. Plan for Change 
5. End-User Acceptance 
6. Change Board Approval
7. Backout Plan 
8. Document Changes

Selected Answer: C
Risk analysis is done in the beginning of the change management process and the others go after it.

this is the whole question......."A business unit wants to upgrade the current of its loan processing software. A manager is putting together a change management request and gathering information on the software. Which of the following would be the most important during the phase of the request process?"
I just made further research on the question. "...wants to upgrade the current software..." End-user acceptance is correct!

Selected Answer: D
"Which of the following should the technician perform FIRST to resolve the problem?"

The least intrusive procedure should always be chosen first, so the answer is "check the host file".

"Reset Internet Explorer settings" would be the second proposal in the options presented in this question.

The correct answer is D
D would be the correct option. Not a single mention of internet explorer even in the question guys.

if the problem exists in all web-based services C might be the answer since resetting the browser works for all web-based services but existed in certain web-based services so the best answer must be D
The simpliest task tech could perform would be (D).

Now that you know that you can't access a site or service on the Internet, you may want to do something about it.

It may not always be possible, however, as connectivity issues are not always issues that you may fix on your end.

Here is a list of suggestions:

Try a different web browser or the same browser in private browsing mode. If you use extensions, I suggest you try a clean, unmodified profile or a different browser.
Check if security software on your device blocks access to the site. You need to check the log of a firewall, or temporarily disable security software to find out.
Check if your Hosts file has an entry for the site in question.
Use third-party tools like Domain Health Report or Blacklist Check to find out if a site is on a blacklist (and thus blocked).
Run a search on Twitter, Reddit or other near real-time services to find out if the site is down for others, or if the operators of the site have published information.
Open the Developer Tools of your browser, usually with F12, and switch to the network tab. Reload the site in question and check if you get errors there.

How can we assume the browser in use is "Internet Explorer" out of the many browsers in the market? option C cannot be the answer. D is the answer given the fact that it is a file that redirects requests to where their domain exists.

comments.content: If the question is explicitly referencing Internet Explorer then that is the browser that is in use. Also, the question is asking which would you perform FIRST. The easiest and quickest thing is to reset the browser setting. I think D is correct.
I agree with C, start First with the easiest and least intrusive option.

Your explanation is going to C. 
I agree

discussion.content: wouldn't you always "check" before performing any action? such as resetting a browser? Resetting the browser to default may make things worse if on a corporate device. Such as resetting the proxy server settings. I am going with D.
Other types of malware change the computer's DNS settings or add various entries to your operating system's Hosts file. D is correct
Why isn't it D?

comments.content:
Actually, this could be one of those questions that wish to know the process of virus removal.
If that's the case then B technically would be the answer because the technician removed the virus and now must ensure virus signatures are updated which would be their FIRST step before dealing with the remaining issues.

I'd say though that it could go B then C then D. But still saying C or D first, then if the issue persists try B and redo C and D.

I would assume changing the settings in the browser is an easier FIRST step to take, then checking checking the hosts file.

Its one of those answers where you're not wrong, but they want you to be. Both C and D are correct technically.

questions.question_text:
A user's computer was infected with malware, and a technician successfully removed the infection. However, the user reports certain web-based services are still inaccessible.
Which of the following should the technician perform FIRST to resolve the issue?

discussion.content: B. exFAT

From Mike Meyers' book:

"Linux file system capabilities exceed those of both macOS and
Windows, being able to read and write to NTFS, FAT32, exFAT, HFS+, and
ext4. Sweet!"

And:

"FAT32 only supports drives up to 2 TB and files up to 4 GB."
"The newer file system, called exFAT, breaks the 4-GB file-size barrier,
supporting files up to 16 exabytes (EB) and a theoretical partition limit of 64
zettabytes (ZB)."

Therefore, MCSA11 is right. Must be exFAT.

Selected Answer: B
Every version of Windows comes with a built-in formatting utility with which to create one or more file systems on a partition or volume. The versions of Windows in current use support three Microsoft file systems: FAT32, NTFS, and exFAT (for removable media).
From (approximately) July 2019, Linuxmint completely supports exfat at the kernel level, which means that each new Linuxmint will work with the exFat format.

Selected Answer: B
exFAT. Fat32 can't hold 4TB

Selected Answer: B
B. exFAT
NFS would be correct

exFAT is a good option if you work often with Windows and Mac computers. Transferring files between the two operating systems is less of a hassle, since you don’t have to constantly back up and reformat each time. Linux is also supported, but you will need to install appropriate software to take full advantage of it. Unfortunately, exFAT didn’t inherit all of FAT32’s legacy in compatibility because it may not work with older devices, such as the PS3 and Xbox 360. It does work on the current-gen of gaming consoles, such as the PS4 and the Xbox One.
Reading these all comments on the question I will be confused if one of these questions will appear in the exam... Not taking credibility to the users, of course.
FAT32 has limits. 2GB files as a ceiling. Can only be formatted up to 2TB per partition so you could theoretically have 2 partitions in FAT32 that are 2TB each on that single drive

questions.question_text:
A customer wants to format a 4TB external drive with a filesystem that is compatible with both Windows and Linux OSs.
Which of the following should the technician suggest the customer use?
